title: Blue and white dish with deer motif

  physical_appearance: This is a Ming dynasty Kraak porcelain. Its exterior is decorated with vegetative motifs upon which a lone bird rests. Its interior rim is decorated with alternating cartouches that enclose flowers. Its central medallion features five deer amidst a rocky landscape where pine trees are found in the right corner.

  subject_terms_1: porcelain paintings (visual works)  symbolism  floral patterns  freehand drawings (drawings)  Chinese export porcelain

  context_1: The dish was exhibited in the Exhibition of Chinese Blue-and-White Ceramics exhibition held at the National Museum of Singapore in April 1978. It is featured as number 157 in the exhibition catalogue.

  sgcool_label_text: The central medallion of the dish features five deer amid a rocky landscape. This is a representative example of Kraak porcelain which is distinguished by a thinly potted body and a decorative scheme divided into rectangular panels containing freely drawn figures and scenes. \r\n\r\nThe term ‘Kraak’ was probably derived from the word ‘carrack’ referring to a type of Portuguese trading vessel. It might have also come from the Dutch word kraken which means ‘to break’ or the name for a style of shelves used for porcelain display in Dutch homes.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
The central medallion of the dish features five deer amid a rocky landscape. This is a representative example of Kraak porcelain which is distinguished by a thinly potted body and a decorative scheme divided into rectangular panels containing freely drawn figures and scenes. 

The term ‘Kraak’ was probably derived from the word ‘carrack’ referring to a type of Portuguese trading vessel. It might have also come from the Dutch word kraken which means ‘to break’ or the name for a style of shelves used for porcelain display in Dutch homes.
